title: Concluding Session

presenter: Thorsten Joachims, Department of Computer Science, Cornell University
Geoff Webb, Faculty of Information Technology, Monash University

segmentation: We made it to the closing all good things must come to an end.
This was a great thing.
Biggest candy ever.
I think we did a great job, but we really could not have done it without everybody who's now?
Rushing to leave, but you made it to the very end, and so that's that's great.
It was really all of you who made this KDD the best, the best KDD that I've certainly participated in and I think we are on hopefully a good trend to to do more or some things.
So one of the things that I thought was really great as I thought we did awesome with getting all the social good theme throughout everything we did here.
We had great participation by the industry and Bloomberg really really helped out as well.
To make this a great event.
I think all the talks, both on the research and industry tracks were were great.
In that sense, I think this was was a great success.

We had a huge amount of attendees here and we were really worried that there was not enough room, but as far as I could see, walking through the conference, it was not too much of an issue, so I'm really really happy with that.
So thank you for that.
I really appreciate it.
One of the things that no, no, because we have really.
I just wanted to.
I had to play with a few more numbers.
I was really interested where everybody was coming from.
Where was this really?
Where the growth was coming performed but also hard as is actually split up.
So I just want to very briefly say few things and actually Torsten, you and Jeff is going to come up and tell you again why you should come to Sydney next year.
So just it's going to be 3 four minutes I promise.
So one of the things that I thought was really really great here is that where did you all come from?
Clearly the US.
But we also have a really great attendance from everybody else here.
Call us here is based on quantiles, because otherwise the major countries would really just dominate.
But here you can see where people are coming from, which was really great really from all over the world.
We even had a little bit from fall in the middle of Africa, which I thought was great.
We had some great broadening participation.
I think most able to.
Also, that workshop was able to get some other minorities in there, which I thought was great.
What we see is from academia.
It was very close to 5050 between faculty and students students.
Just edged out on the 50 percentile, so that was great for first time ever.
Industry actually had more participation than they could email I believe, and we also had some from government.
So many things I thought was interesting.
If you look at where the industry was coming from, one of the things that I notice was that South America, South Africa, all the people from South Africa Mid Africa is good.
We have a little few people there were from industry interesting enough also from parts of Europe.
I'm not going to go into the yard numbers too much, but part of Europe also.
Everybody that came from from some areas in your particular skindinavia also seem to be only from industry.
We have a fair amount of people also from.
Crosses across the board.
There so you can see here some of these colors went away when we went to the to the academics.
Only one of the things that we saw, the African disappeared.
Some of Scandinavia disappeared.
We see some more interesting dynamics in South America here that I thought was interesting.
One of the things that was interesting was if you look at the academics where the faculty.
Coming from, we have a really good representation here.
But when I looked at where the students are coming from, you actually saw some countries kind of disappear.
I'm not going to name them here, but it was interesting.

There was actually a couple of countries where we only had faculty participation and none of their students came, and I'm not quite sure what happened there, but hopefully we can fix that in future years.
But All in all, I was really, really happy we had a great crowd here and before we move on.
And everybody leaves.
I wanted to say this also could not have happened without the great organizing committee.
And frankly, the mean Claudius we were at the top.
But frankly, the whole committee was just awesome and we could not have done it with everybody on that committee.
So I really want to have a great thank you for everybody there on that committee who worked their asses off to make this happen.
So just so, let's give them.
I had a James so Hutson from Bloomberg down there at the bottom right as an honorary part of the organizing committee to help with the Bloomberg and I think frankly they did an awesome job.
So thank you, James.
So with that, I think I wanted to say that feedback, good and bad, send it to us.
We really would like to hear the good and the bad.
I'm not going to take questions here because that would just be few tile but send us.
Send us email because I really, really want to know, especially if there's things you liked and didn't like.
So with that, I think we want to give it up to Torsten Jeffrey if you can come and say a little bit about why we should be coming to Sydney.
At the very end we actually have just a futures down here.
If anybody want a KDD shirt, come grab them, but before that, Torsten Jeff.
Are you guys around somewhere?
They are.
Yeah, I was told to use a Canon.
Just shoot them up, but I don't think I'm going to be quite there.
Thank you so KTD 2015.
The world's most iconic data mining conference.
In one of the world's most iconic cities in the greatest country on Earth.
We are looking for your support to make this the greatest KDD conference.
In order to fit the greatest country.
Also, please send us saw any suggestions you have and on that note.
I'll leave you with our.
Invitation to join us to allow us to host you in Australia.
In August 2015.
Thank you.
You guys coming back?
Then let's give another big thank you to sofas and Claudia, who really pulled this program together, and I think that should be the last of loss of the conference.
